TextBlock.TextLine: In Antwerpen 2 January 1681
Brussel Philip van vorselaer
Monsr. tot advies als dat op passatto ul. bewijs tot last van dien heer
tot gent hebbe wederom gesonden, niet twijeffelende oft ul heeft het
sel ve wel ontfangen, oversulx nu seer verlegen sijnde om gelt heb
devryigheyt genomen op ul te trecken op t a 2 d sight bijftigh
ponden te betaelen aen d'ordre van monsr. thom. mulans hebbende
de weirde alhier ontfangen, en alsoo dat op de beurse is getraiteert
en magh hier geen manquement in sijn, want mijn respect
& reditt dependert daer van, terwijlen
In Antord 5 Janu 16819
Mons Pierre Meurant
Mons. vous ayant southaitted vre heureuse novelle anne in largerey a l vre
du 29 passato les 31: ditto vous ayant donne advis que j'ay alors receu l vre
sur ditte avec la lettre de change de500 .D: vant fustement £102:14:2
a la charge d'Petro andrea martini les quell at accepte, estant du 15 dgb
auso d renise que fait trois mois icy, tellement serat recen du 15 d januies
il est Bor Jeloing maopinion quand vous envoye les antre je n'ay
manqueray pas desuiier vre ordre pour les present je n'ay pas afaire
quelle argent a Brugges ny a Lille pour les railons donner la
Nanx
presentande, entre temps j'espere les overte enpeude jour Enfin que nre
marchandise peuvent arrive de Brugge ou que j'aij un grand deraye
arrive pour moy, Depuis je demeurey
In Antwarp 3 Janu82-
Lille Rich Southell
S. haneing wished you an happy, prosperons & sices full new yeare and as many
Blessings as you desire come to an answer to both yd of 23 & 29 pass the cold
weather & frost hath hindred my writing as well letters as in my bookes butt this
mill weather hath brought met to itt againe this day I do exspect yd acctt. hopeing
you disposed of all our goods in comp. that so you be able to putt the same
valew to afresh imploy: because I finde my selfs so well provided with
standing out debts that I am al togheter imable to comply with the
needfull of my occasions, whoever when you are in England shall desired yd advis
of what passes, as also what others do intimate you about our trade hered
princippally I.k who can not yett leave his pratt les as soone I have yd acctt
shall acvise you what isright as to the concernes of yd freind mr. Herreford
I have putt itt in worck, butt the woman he mentioned is not here lives oe
where in holland (which van ellen would not tell mee pretending that
he doth not know itt salett, m. Herreford write mee what I shall dofuittes
In Antwerpen 8 Janu 1681
Brussel JH. Bonnecvoy
Ick hebbe bij mijnen leeften van ul versoght als dat aen mij soudt gelieve te send
De canten de welke gereet sijn die noch morgen verwaght boven dien heb van doen
een a 2 tolletten van 34 hoogh ten alder alverminst tijf half Elle tsij truillie
ofte in settsels, en will wel ƒ14 a 16: p: Elle besteden, ende iderst uck soude
8 a lanck moet wesen kan ul soodanigh vinde gelieft de voir te doen, en koop
als voor eijgen geen gemaekt sijnde doet een atwee maken liever van
hoogh als minder hier op verwaght ul adves In Antwerpen 8 Janua e681
Brussel Joseph Sabberton
p alter haveing wished you an happy & prosperons, new yeare serves this in ansswer
to yd formars that concerning the desire crawat now Imust intreat you to previde
& or light elles of that lawe with 8016 ells of the same pattarnes for the cute
& this pr first: besides in guire if you kan send mee one or 2 laces wither trailless
without ground of an ell broad 5 4 or att least ½ anell & 2 in cles in prijses
from 14 to 16 guilders anell I must also accquaint you that my womans
buying proved exuding better them yd which Il shew you by letters from England
when one you come here fore pray endeavour a beter whilst I rest
In Antwerp 4 Jan u 1681
London John Loyd
th
S. I have Receaved both yd of 13 & 17 past in which I observe that you formd the
acctt of N. 8„ as also that of the guild leather & that you had receaved the pack of
tykes N.7„ which you complaine of truely I confess I have been long aproviding of
that pack because those goods were extrd ardinary scarey att that time when wee
wee almost constrained to take what best wee could then afford, butt non
in sealed except one that had the seale some what loose which is caused in
the press: yett I hope you disposed of them to content that you will finde amendes
in N.8„ which I have been sensible had not the opportunitie of Red ford mr. coots made
his excuse & sayd that redford weat away in a sturrj without giveing the least
noticce for feare of beeng froven, up thought there was nott such need, & great
deale of goods for his loading ready I shall write him to loose no further conveniency
there is a binlandar ready which I hope shall be able to gett out with this
thouwing weather I shall buy no more tykes for yd acctt. till faither order
altought now I finde the werckmen to want mony & bring every meerket
day new assortments, the opportunitie of which I have not neglected butt brought
a good parcell al ready which I hope will finde their in & intend to lay out
some more mony to wards itt in case they continew in plentifull nesss
thought butt very little abatement I have writt to gent a sout the legecturen
to provide the 32 peeces & to their att most to rimorridge the future contumanced
thuely I have used all the rethoricale would I could then imagine to persuade
them to do well & to dispach with all con vemens speed butt have no answer
yett the least letter advised met that they were att worcktthat thers were
non on handes so I doubt they will so soone ready whoever be confident that
I shall not neglect the opportunitie to promote yd iintrest my tanckes for
accepting of my bill wish you an happy & prosperons new yeare & remaine
In Antwarp 4 janu 1681
London Henry Maynard
th
S my last to you was on the 28: past to which please to be referred sence
have receaved yd of 13 & 17 ditto, for atryall desire you to in order a pack o
goods as by the inclosed patt & instructions from the north, from him, that
you tell mee doth bay in forde mont of this towne by order of John Riches
fuither I observe yd advise con cerning goods in london seeng spanish cloathes are pretty
plentifull I am of opinion that itt will not be and to pick now & then a
cloth according to the inclosed patt., & instructions which buy when you iudge
a penny worth for trade here is attogheter att ostand so the haste is not
reat for them beleaving not to want yd before marck tis onely beccause
you might have now & then yd choyce & good goods to content mony is
also extran agant scarey, and as if with this frost all was froren op, yett
you have a remise as here under there are 3 binl andars arrived at
ostend from London & I can not perceave any thing from Ben: clarck
god send him well over & preserve him from the present torming
weither in less Ican have the frises here in 8 a 10, dayes I doubt the
season for them will be over till next yeare in case m. scawen
hat no more callicoes you need to buy no cottons
what I in order shall be as before I hope you have grecd. the gold by Tis
time from m. Coots, which in case you finde well freely: in order &
Iel provide for what monyes comes due to yd acctt. yd bill of £100
shall accept incloser sind you 2 bills £400: on John lambe
1wot on farnetfereink please to promedhe
need fule. I shoud send you patt. r prnent becaus the
ine s te shot
